definitions: relating to the sounds of human speech and their production or perception
relating to the representation of speech sounds using written symbols or notation
examples: The phonetic alphabet helps pilots communicate clearly
Students studied the phonetic properties of different languages
The dictionary provides phonetic transcriptions for each word
She used phonetic spelling to write unfamiliar words

definitions: not genuine or real but made to appear so deliberately
behaving in a way that is not sincere or genuine to impress others
examples: The police discovered several phoney passports in his apartment
That diamond ring turned out to be completely phoney
His phoney British accent fooled nobody at the party
She saw through his phoney charm immediately

definitions: relating to the study of sound systems and patterns in language
examples: The phonological rules of English differ from those of Japanese
Her research focuses on phonological development in children
The linguist analyzed the phonological structure of the dialect
Phonological awareness is crucial for learning to read

definitions: not genuine or real but made to appear so deliberately
behaving in a way that is not sincere or genuine to impress others
examples: The detective exposed the phony charity organization
They were selling phony designer handbags online
Her phony concern for others was obvious to everyone
Don't give me that phony excuse again

definitions: relating to or containing phosphorus especially in its higher valence state
examples: Phosphoric acid is commonly used in soft drinks
The chemist analyzed the phosphoric compounds in the sample
Industrial processes often require phosphoric fertilizers
The phosphoric content of the soil was measured

definitions: relating to or caused by chemical reactions that are triggered by light
examples: Photochemical smog forms when sunlight reacts with pollutants
The scientist studied photochemical processes in plant cells
Photochemical reactions are essential for photosynthesis
The photochemical decomposition of the compound was observed

definitions: relating to or using the emission of electrons from a surface when light strikes it
examples: The photoelectric effect was explained by Einstein
Photoelectric sensors detect objects using light beams
The burglar alarm uses photoelectric technology
Photoelectric cells convert light into electrical energy

definitions: having features that look attractive when photographed or filmed
examples: She's incredibly photogenic and always looks great in pictures
The photogenic couple posed for wedding photographs
This beach is particularly photogenic at sunset
He discovered he was more photogenic than he thought

definitions: relating to or used in photography or the taking of photographs
having the ability to remember or reproduce something with great accuracy and detail
examples: She collected antique photographic equipment for her studio
The photographic exhibition featured landscapes from around the world
He has a photographic memory for faces and names
Her photographic recall of events proved invaluable

definitions: responding to or affected by light especially in undergoing chemical change
examples: Photosensitive paper darkens when exposed to sunlight
The patient's medication made her skin photosensitive
The photosensitive coating reacts to ultraviolet light
These photosensitive cells trigger the security system

definitions: relating to or capable of photosynthesis the process by which plants make food using light
examples: Photosynthetic organisms convert sunlight into chemical energy
The photosynthetic rate increased under bright light conditions
Green algae are photosynthetic and produce oxygen
Scientists studied the photosynthetic efficiency of different crops

definitions: relating to the direct conversion of light into electricity using semiconducting materials
examples: Photovoltaic panels on the roof generate electricity for the house
The photovoltaic industry has grown rapidly in recent years
They installed a photovoltaic system to reduce energy costs
Photovoltaic cells are becoming more efficient each year

definitions: relating to or consisting of a phrase rather than a single word
examples: English has many phrasal verbs like 'give up' and 'look after'
The phrasal structure of the sentence was analyzed
Students struggled with phrasal expressions in the foreign language
The dictionary includes common phrasal combinations

definitions: relating to the body as opposed to the mind or spirit
existing in a form that can be touched or seen rather than conceptual
relating to physics or the properties and interactions of matter and energy
examples: Regular physical exercise improves cardiovascular health
The doctor performed a thorough physical examination
The physical evidence at the crime scene was conclusive
We need physical proof not just speculation
The physical properties of metals include conductivity
Students studied physical laws governing motion

definitions: relating to the normal functions of living organisms and their parts
examples: The physiologic response to stress includes increased heart rate
Researchers studied the physiologic effects of the medication
Normal physiologic processes maintain body temperature
The physiologic mechanisms of digestion are complex

definitions: relating to the normal functions of living organisms and their parts
examples: The physiological effects of exercise are well documented
Scientists measured physiological responses to the treatment
Hunger is a basic physiological need for all animals
The physiological basis of memory is still being researched

definitions: played or performed softly and quietly in musical notation
examples: The piano passage should be played with delicate touch
The conductor signaled for a piano dynamic in the strings
The piece begins piano before building to forte
She sang the lullaby piano to soothe the baby

definitions: relating to fiction depicting the adventures of a roguish but appealing hero
examples: The picaresque novel follows the hero through various escapades
His picaresque tales entertained audiences for hours
The film has a picaresque quality with its wandering narrative
She wrote a picaresque memoir of her travels

definitions: of little value or importance; concerned with insignificant details
examples: Don't waste time on such picayune matters
His picayune complaints annoyed everyone in the meeting
The editor made picayune changes that didn't improve the text
She refused to be drawn into picayune arguments

definitions: preserved in vinegar or brine solution for flavor or storage
very drunk from consuming too much alcohol in informal usage
examples: The pickled vegetables added tang to the sandwich
She served pickled herring as an appetizer
He was completely pickled after the office party
They found him pickled at the bar again

definitions: expressed in pictures or illustrations rather than words; relating to pictures
examples: The pictorial guide made assembly instructions easy to follow
She created a pictorial history of the town
The magazine features pictorial essays on travel destinations
Children's books often use pictorial narratives

definitions: represented or shown in a picture photograph or illustration
examples: The pictured items are available for immediate purchase
All pictured models wore designer clothing
The pictured scene depicts life in medieval times
As pictured above the device has three main components

definitions: visually attractive especially in a quaint or charming old-fashioned way
examples: The picturesque village attracted many tourists each summer
They stayed in a picturesque cottage by the lake
The old windmill made a picturesque addition to the landscape
Venice is one of Europe's most picturesque cities

definitions: done or made gradually in separate stages rather than all at once
examples: The piecemeal approach to reform proved ineffective
They released information in a piecemeal fashion
The building underwent piecemeal renovation over several years
His piecemeal efforts failed to solve the problem

definitions: having two or more different colors especially in irregular patches
examples: The pied piper wore a coat of many colors
A pied horse grazed in the meadow
The bird's pied plumage made it easy to identify
She admired the pied pattern of the butterfly's wings

definitions: having had holes made through something especially for decorative purposes
examples: Her pierced ears displayed elegant diamond studs
The pierced metal screen allowed air to circulate
He wore a ring through his pierced eyebrow
The pierced leather belt had an intricate pattern

definitions: sharp and able to make a hole; producing sharp sensation
extremely cold in a way that seems to penetrate the body
showing keen insight or perception; seeming to see through things
examples: A piercing scream echoed through the night
The piercing whistle hurt their ears
The piercing wind cut through their winter coats
It was a piercing cold morning in January
She fixed him with a piercing stare
His piercing analysis revealed the truth

definitions: having characteristics associated with pigs such as small eyes or snout
showing greed especially with food or possessions like a pig
examples: His piggy eyes squinted in the bright sunlight
The child made piggy noises while playing
Don't be so piggy with the candy
Her piggy behavior at dinner embarrassed everyone

definitions: having been robbed violently especially during war or riot
examples: The pillaged village lay in ruins after the invasion
Pillaged treasures were recovered from the thieves
The museum displayed artifacts from pillaged tombs
The pillaged stores remained closed for weeks

definitions: supported by or decorated with pillars or columns in architecture
examples: The pillared entrance impressed all visitors to the mansion
They walked through the pillared hallway to the ballroom
The ancient pillared temple still stood after centuries
A pillared portico provided shade from the sun

definitions: pressed tightly between finger and thumb or compressed into small space
showing signs of suffering poverty or hardship especially in facial features
examples: Her pinched fingers struggled with the tiny clasp
The pinched nerve caused shooting pain down his arm
His pinched face showed years of poverty
She had a pinched look from constant worry

definitions: of a pale red color like that of pink flowers or salmon
showing good health with rosy cheeks informal usage
examples: She wore a pink dress to the spring wedding
The pink roses bloomed beautifully in the garden
After the vacation he was in the pink of health
The baby's pink cheeks showed she was thriving

definitions: having a slight pink color or tinge; somewhat pink
examples: The sunset cast a pinkish glow over the mountains
Her skin had a pinkish tone after the sunburn
The pinkish hue of the pearl made it valuable
He noticed a pinkish tint in the water

definitions: showing deep religious devotion and reverence for deity
making a display of virtue or righteousness especially hypocritically
examples: The pious monk spent hours in daily prayer
Her pious devotion inspired the congregation
His pious pronouncements concealed his corrupt dealings
She was tired of his pious lectures about morality

definitions: extremely angry or annoyed about something informal usage
drunk from consuming too much alcohol British informal usage
examples: She was really pissed about the cancelled flight
He got pissed when they ignored his suggestions
They were completely pissed after the pub crawl
He was too pissed to drive home safely

definitions: set or fixed at a particular angle or slope especially of roofs
having a particular musical pitch or tone level of sound
examples: The steeply pitched roof shed rain efficiently
They installed windows in the pitched attic space
Her high-pitched voice carried across the room
The low-pitched hum came from the refrigerator

definitions: expressing much in few words; brief forceful and meaningful in expression
examples: Her pithy comments summed up the entire debate perfectly
The professor was known for pithy observations about literature
He delivered a pithy response that silenced his critics
The book is full of pithy sayings and quotations

definitions: arousing pity especially through vulnerability or sadness
deserving contempt because of inadequacy or poor quality
examples: The pitiful sight of homeless children moved her to tears
His pitiful expression begged for forgiveness
Their pitiful attempt at deception fooled nobody
The team's pitiful performance disappointed their fans

definitions: marked by small hollows indentations or scars on the surface
having had the pit or stone removed from fruit
examples: His pitted skin showed scars from teenage acne
The pitted metal surface needed refinishing
She bought pitted olives for the salad
The recipe calls for pitted cherries

definitions: relating to the small endocrine gland at the base of the brain
examples: The pituitary gland regulates various hormones in the body
She had surgery to remove a pituitary tumor
Pituitary hormones control growth and metabolism
The doctor ordered pituitary function tests

definitions: of crucial importance in the development or success of something
examples: Her research played a pivotal role in finding the cure
That meeting proved pivotal to the company's future
The general made a pivotal decision during the battle
This is a pivotal moment in our nation's history

definitions: put in a particular position or location; situated somewhere
examples: The carefully placed decorations enhanced the room's ambiance
A strategically placed camera monitored the entrance
The well-placed investment yielded significant returns
Her perfectly placed shot won the tennis match

definitions: relating to the organ that nourishes a fetus during pregnancy
examples: The placental tissue was examined after delivery
Placental mammals give birth to live young
The doctor checked for placental abnormalities
Placental blood flow affects fetal development

definitions: not easily upset or excited; calm and peaceful in temperament or appearance
examples: The placid lake reflected the mountains perfectly
Her placid demeanor calmed everyone in the room
The placid baby rarely cried or fussed
He maintained a placid expression during the interrogation

definitions: taken and used as one's own work without crediting the original source
examples: The plagiarized essay resulted in the student's expulsion
Several plagiarized passages were found in the manuscript
The professor identified plagiarized content using detection software
His plagiarized speech damaged his political career

definitions: not decorated or elaborate; simple and basic in character
easy to perceive or understand; clear and obvious
not beautiful or attractive in appearance lacking beauty
having a flat level surface without hills or mountains
examples: She wore a plain white dress to the ceremony
The room had plain walls with no decorations
The plain truth is that we can't afford it
It's plain to see that they're in love
She considered herself rather plain compared to her sister
His plain features were unremarkable
The vast plain stretched for miles in every direction
Buffalo once roamed these plains in huge herds

definitions: sounding sad and mournful especially in a way that expresses suffering
examples: The plaintive cry of the lost puppy touched everyone's heart
A plaintive melody drifted from the violin
Her plaintive voice begged for understanding
The bird's plaintive call echoed through the forest

definitions: relating to or lying in a plane; flat or two-dimensional
examples: The planar surface of the crystal was perfectly smooth
Engineers designed a planar antenna for the device
The molecule has a planar structure with all atoms in one plane
They studied planar geometry in mathematics class

definitions: completely flat and level forming a smooth surface
examples: The carpenter ensured the plane surface was perfectly smooth
The plane mirror reflected light evenly
They needed a plane surface for the precision measurement
The plane geometry problem required careful calculation

definitions: relating to or belonging to a planet or planets in the solar system
examples: The planetary alignment occurs rarely in astronomical history
Scientists study planetary atmospheres to understand climate
The planetary system contains eight major planets
Planetary exploration has revealed fascinating discoveries
